Title: the terminator decoupling

Howard: Okay, Raj, hand me the number six torque screwdriver.
For taking daffodils to your unicorn.
Yeah, cool. Seven times as long as flying, and costs almost twice as much.
Come on, Raj.
It can’t be. What would Summer Glau be doing riding the train?
Sheldon, I owe you an apology. Taking the train was a stroke of brilliance! I’ve actually got a shot at a Terminator.

You’re overlooking something. I have 11 hours with her in a confined space. Unless she’s willing to jump off a moving train, tuck and roll down the side of a hill, she will eventually succumb to the acquired taste that is Howard Wolowitz.
Sheldon, let me explain to you how this works.
That’s Summer Glau.
That’s it.
Um, well, let’s see, couple reasons. One, I saw her first.
Fair enough. But then let me move on to number two, unlike you, I can actually talk to women when I’m sober.
Well, you know the old saying, pasty and frail never fail.
Fine, go ahead. Take a shot.
I will, I’m just working on my opening line.
No, no, no, that always creeps girls out. I need to come up with something that’s funny, smart and delicately suggests that my sexual endowment is disproportionate to my physical stature.
Do you believe him? Normally around women, he has the personality of a boiled potato. Put one beer in him, and he’s M. Night Charmalarmalon.
What?
What’s going on?
Placebo, you say. Interesting.
Raj.
Look.
You tell me.
Hi, I’m the small package good things come in.

So anyway, in the dream, you and I were ice skating, just the two of us. And then, I picked you up by your ankles and twirled you round and round until your legs tore off. I tried to stick them back on, but before I could, you turned into a giant loaf of pumpernickel bread. What do you think that means?
I’ll give you a little clue. My favourite sandwich? Salami on pumpernickel.
And did you know the word “pumpernickel” comes from the German words pumper and nickel, which loosely translates to fart goblin?
Okay, here’s another one. If you married the famous rock guitarist Johnny Winter, you’d be Summer Winter.
Okay, I’m going to just go for broke here and say I like you.
So here’s my question, do you realistically see any conversational path that would take me from where we are right now to a place where I could ask you out and you’d say yes?
Fair enough. I’ll leave you in peace.
But before I go, would you mind if I just take one picture of us together for my Facebook page?
Okay. Great. Now, can I take one where it looks like we’re making out?
Terminator broke my phone.
Sheldon: Stop. We can’t do this, it’s not right.

But once you open the box, you’ve voided the warranty. The warranty is a sacred covenant we’ve entered into with the manufacturer. He offers to stand by his equipment, and we in return agree not to violate the integrity of the internal hardware. This little orange sticker is all that stands between us and anarchy.

I understand your envy. This is a can’t-miss symposium. There are going to be discussions on bioorganic cellular computer devices, the advancements in multi-threaded task completion, plus a roundtable on the nonequilibrium Green’s function approach to the photoionization process in atoms.

George Smoot is a Nobel Prize-winning physicist, one of the great minds of our time. His work in black body form and anisotropy of the cosmic microwave background radiation cemented our understanding of the origin of the universe.
It’s like talking to a chimp.
We’re not flying, we’re taking the train.
Oh, I always enjoy that, but I’m a little busy.

I’m simplifying the task of packing for our trip. See, by attaching RFID tags to my clothing, it will enable my laptop to read and identify the items with this wand. I will then cross-reference them against destination, anticipated activity spectrum, weather conditions, duration of trip, et cetera.
Assuming I can keep up this pace, three hours, 11 minutes, and plus however long it takes to conclude this fairly pointless conversation.
I don’t follow.
Socks, one pair, cotton, argyle, blue. Socks, one pair, cotton, argyle, blue.
What on earth are you doing?

Gentlemen, this is the Coast Starlight, one of the great American trains operating on one of the classic American routes. On this side, you’ll see panoramic ocean vistas inaccessible to any other form of transportation, while on your side, you’ll be treated to 350 miles of CostCos, Jiffy Lubes, and cinderblock homes with above-ground pools.
No.
That’s over the wheelbase. Are you completely unfamiliar with the suspension characteristics of a pre-1980 Pullman-built Superliner Deluxe passenger coach?
Here. I’m hoping once you reap the endorphic rewards of the steady clickety-clack of steel wheels on polished rails, your sour disposition will abate.
He is referring, of course, to third class on Indian Railways’ magnificent Ranakpur Express and its twelve hundred kilometer journey from Maharashtra to the Bikaner Junction.
Unlikely. That’s a television show, Leonard.

Of course, if SkyNet actually did exist in the future, a perfect way to infiltrate and destroy mankind would be to send Terminators back posing as actors who have played Terminators in popular films and television series, lulling us into a false sense of security, i.e., that’s Summer Glau from The Sarah Connor Chronicles. No, Summer, don’t kill me! I’m pro-robot! Ahh!
Whee!
I’m confused. I thought you were involved in some sort of socially intimate pairing with Leslie Winkle.
All right.
Yes.
Interesting that you ask. The Coast Starlight recently added the refurbished Pacific Parlour Car. Built in 1956 and originally known as the Santa Fe Lounge Car, the lower level is a theatre…
and the upper level is a bar that offers wine tastings if you’re going as far as Portland.
Oh, no.
I forgot my flash drive.
So we have to go back.
You don’t understand. My flash drive has my paper on astrophysical probes of M-theory effects in the early universe that I was going to give to George Smoot at the conference.
It’s brilliant. He needs to read it.
Then I won’t get to see his face light up as he reads it.
Oh, this is an unmitigated disaster.
You forgot your flash drive, You forgot your flash drive (repeated over and over in time to the sound of the train)
Are you going to be sarcastic?
But the flash drive is in a locked drawer in my desk.
The key is hidden in my room.
Penny would have to go into my room.
People don’t go in my room!
Oh, I hate when that happens.
Okay, step four. Do you see that small plastic case on my dresser?
It’s Sheldon.
I’m not in San Francisco. I’m on a train. Were you even listening to me?
What’s up? I’ll tell you what’s up. I’m in a crisis situation, and I need you to marshal your powers of concentration, limited as they may be…
Okay. Enough chitchat. Okay, step one, locate your emergency key to our apartment. Step two, enter our apartment. Step three, enter my bedroom.
No! Leonard, let me tell you something. Personal robots cannot get here soon enough.
All right, now, before you enter my bedroom unescorted, I need you to understand that this onetime grant of access does not create a permanent easement. Easement. It’s a legal right

Yes, I’m still here. Where am I going? I’m on a train. Now, what you’ll be looking for is a small wooden box located between a Hoberman’s sphere and a sample of quartz flecked with pyrite. Hoberman’s Sphere. It’s a collapsible icosidodecahedron. No, the thing with the time on it is my alarm clock.
That’s the wrong box. Put it back.
Don’t read those letters!
Put down the letters!
I’m back.
Nobody calls me Moon Pie but Meemaw!

You’re holding a Japanese puzzle box, which takes ten precise moves to open. First, locate the panel with the diamond pattern and slide the centre portion one millimetre to the left. Then, on the opposite end of the box, slide the entire panel down two millimetres. You’ll hear a slight click.
No, it’s a novelty I ordered off the Internet. Now, did you hear the click?

Okay, now you’re going to insert the flash drive into the USB port. She calls me Moon Pie because I’m nummy-nummy and she could just eat me up, now, please put the flash drive in the USB port. The one that looks like a little duck’s mouth.

So, I’m thinking, you won the Nobel Prize what, three years ago? So you must deal with a whole lot of what has Smoot done lately? My thought is we continue my research as a team, you know, Cooper-Smoot, alphabetical, and when we win the Nobel Prize, you’ll be back on top.
Fine! Smoot-Cooper. Wow, what a diva.
Raj: Sheldon, you have two choices. Either you let him put a bigger hard drive in the TiVo, or you delete stuff before we go out of town.
Whatever it is, I’m guessing we’re doing it wrong.
What’s wrong with Jiffy Lubes?
It’s not so bad, really. At least these trains have modern plumbing. In India, you squat over a hole in the train and expose your naked buttocks to the chilly air of Rajasthan.
Holy crap! Look!
Oh, please.When it comes to Terminators, you’ve got a better shot of scoring with Arnold Schwarzenegger.
Hang on a sec. Why do you get first crack at her?
No, you didn’t. I did.
You fail to take into account that even mute, I am foreign and exotic, while you, on the other hand, are frail and pasty.
Sheldon, is there a place on this train to get alcohol?
Yeah-yeah, which way?
Really? I just made it up. Have you seen Slumdog Millionaire?
It’s loosely based on my life.
And that bright little star peeking her head out early today, that’s Venus.
Come on. When you were on TV in Firefly, you were actually in space.
You mean one of the hopeless geeks? No. Those are crazy people. Howard, be a dear and get me another one of these. Now, him, he’s one of those geeks.
Actually, in India, the names of constellations are different. Where you have the Big Dipper, we have the Big Curry Pot.
You got me. Now what are you going to do with me?
Yes?
What am I looking at?
Non-alcoholic bee-ee-eeuh (Runs off)
Leonard: Okay, then we won’t touch the hard drive. We’ll just erase the first season of Battlestar.
It’s perfect.
It’s just for my notebooks. Thanks, Penny.
This conference is kind of a big thing. The keynote address is being delivered by George Smoot.
You’ve heard of him?
Yeah, I wish.
Well, we had a vote. Three of us voted for airplane, Sheldon voted for train, so we’re taking the train.
Hey, we’re all going over to the Apple store to make fun of the guys at the Genius Bar. You want to come?
What are you doing?
Well, that does sound much simpler. How long is this going to take?
Wow. Teasing the guys at the Apple store seems a little redundant now.
I wouldn’t expect you to. I’ll see you later.
Why not?
Sheldon, we’ve been on this train 90 seconds, and you’ve already said a thousand words. Just tell us where to sit and shut up.
Yeah, maybe. Meanwhile back in the 21st century, people are raising their tray tables and putting their seat-backs in an upright position ’cause it’s time to land in San Francisco.
Oh, look, now he’s boring on an international scale.
Is that who I think it is?
Maybe John Connor’s aboard and she’s protecting him from an evil Terminator.
Thank you.
At least he’s off the train crap.
My money’s on tuck and roll.
Excuse me, but what about me? Why don’t I get a shot?
You know, I’ve already got a gorgeous blonde back home at I can’t score with. I think I’ll let you two take this one.
So aren’t you going to go talk to her?
She’s probably heard every possible line, Howard. Why don’t you just try hello?
You’re going to need more than 11 hours.
What’s the matter?
So?
Okay, Sheldon, I’m going to say why and your answer cannot be because I forgot my flash drive.
Why do you have to give your paper to George Smoot?
So you’ll send him an e-mail when we get back.
Right. Of course.
Well, there’s nothing you can do about it, so relax, sit back, enjoy the clickety-clack of the steel wheels on the polished rails.
Only ten hours, 55 minutes to go.
I’ve got a better idea.
Boy, you take all the fun out of it for me.  But look, Penny’s home. Why don’t we just call her, have her go in the apartment, get your flash drive and e-mail you the paper?
So?
So?
So?
I see. Well, it seems once again, you’re caught between a rock and a crazy place.
Give me the phone. Hi, Penny. It’s Leonard.
He’s calling to ask you a favour. You might be confused because he didn’t use the words, Penny, Sheldon, please or favour.
Is that what he’s drinking? It’s not even real beer.
Look at it. Non-alcoholic beer.
I don’t know. Some sort of placebo effect, I guess.
Hey, Penny. It’s Leonard.
Delightful. Listen, I don’t know what you’re doing right now, but there are little bubbles forming on the corners of Sheldon’s mouth.
Thank you.
Hey, Penny. Leonard again.
Hey, how’d it go?
Hi, my name’s Leonard.
Penny (entering with a pink suitcase): Here you go, Leonard. Is this going to be big enough?
Penny: Oh, I love San Francisco. I wish I was going with you.
When I go, I usually just get hammered and ride the cable cars.
Oh, my God, the George Smoot?
Of course I haven’t.
It’s kind of a funny name, though, Smoot.
Okay, now that I’ve been completely insulted, have a good flight.
Oh, cool.

Yeah, we’re putting the play on for one night in this little 99-seat theatre. Can you come? Oh, great. Do you know 98 other people that might want to come? Oh, hang on. (Switches to another line) Hello?

You’re holding a Japanese puzzle box, which takes ten precise moves to open. First, locate the panel with the diamond pattern and slide the centre portion one millimetre to the left. Then, on the opposite end of the box, slide the entire panel down two millimetres. You’ll hear a slight click.
Hang on. Sheldon, do you have any emotional attachment to this box?
No, it’s a novelty I ordered off the Internet. Now, did you hear the click?
Not yet. (Puts box on ground and stomps on it)There it is.
Okay, here’s another one. If you married the famous rock guitarist Johnny Winter, you’d be Summer Winter.
Okay, I’m going to just go for broke here and say I like you.
So here’s my question, do you realistically see any conversational path that would take me from where we are right now to a place where I could ask you out and you’d say yes?
Fair enough. I’ll leave you in peace.
But before I go, would you mind if I just take one picture of us together for my Facebook page?
Okay. Great. Now, can I take one where it looks like we’re making out?

Okay, now you’re going to insert the flash drive into the USB port. She calls me Moon Pie because I’m nummy-nummy and she could just eat me up, now, please put the flash drive in the USB port. The one that looks like a little duck’s mouth.

Leonard: Excuse me. (Goes down to Summer) Okay, I’ll be honest with you. I’ve just spent the last two hours imagining various scenarios in my head, trying to come up with some clever line to say to you. But then I finally realized you’re a human being
I’m a human being. I could just say to you…

So, I’m thinking, you won the Nobel Prize what, three years ago? So you must deal with a whole lot of what has Smoot done lately? My thought is we continue my research as a team, you know, Cooper-Smoot, alphabetical, and when we win the Nobel Prize, you’ll be back on top.
With all due respect, Dr. Cooper, are you on crack?
Fine! Smoot-Cooper. Wow, what a diva.
